biggest impacts to Performance there's a lot of things you can do managing your file sizes using modern image formats
but there's also some HML approaches you can take as well now I almost didn't include this next one but it's really
important and it's the easiest way to improve the performance of your page and that is adding a width and
height to your images because what this will do will improve the effect of the cumulative layout shift which as an
aside I have spent so long trying to say that word it is very difficult to say in
front of a bunch of people and I'm so chuffed that I just got it right let's see if I can do it again so
the cumulative layout shift measures how many element how much elements on the page shift as content is being
downloaded with images this is particularly important because there's typically a delay between the HTML and
the image being downloaded and this can cause any content below the image to be pushed down the page causing a layout
shift really disruptive and annoying especially if you've already started reading because it's going to start
jumping down the page now you probably notice this a lot on mobile devices because of the smaller screen real
estate but the problem with this is it can become even worse if you think about
this is one image if you had another image below it that load in pushes everything down again and then it
happens again it's kind of like a domino effect and this domino effect can
significantly increase the work of the browser as it has to recalculate the layout every single time an image is
loaded in so by adding the width and a height you kind of reserve the space for the
image meaning that the browser doesn't have to recalculate all of the nodes in the page every time an image is loaded
in it's just going to load in place now going back to the date of
birth thing uh if you were around pre- responsive web design you will note that we used to do this all the time we used
to add a width and a height to our images but when responsive web design became a thing we stopped doing it
because you can't have a 1,000 pixel wide image on a 400 pixel wide
device so we had to add in some additional attributes to manage this and
the first one is Source set which allows you to provide a comma separated list of image file names with a width or density
descriptor so the density is the DPI the image in this case I've defined two
images uh one jelly 1000 which is 1,000 wide and jelly 200000 which is 2,000
wide the 1,000 W indicates what the width of the image is so that the browser doesn't have to download it to
know what the size is sometimes people think that the 1000 w means width of the viewport um it does not it means width
of the image if you want to determine which image to use based on the width of the viewport you can use the sizes
attribute which allows you to define media conditions like we do in CSS so we
can say at a minwidth of 1,000 pixels I want to load a 1,000 pixel wide image
and then it will go to that Source set and it will pick the one that matches in this case the 1,000 wide
image if there isn't one that matches it will pick the next largest one so in
this case I've not specified a 400 pixel wide image so it will go and load a th000 regardless which isn't great um
but that's what you can use souret and sizes for now there are a bunch of other things you can do um especially in CSS

it is because some image management components or libraries will lazy load

in view when the page first starts loading so that top part of your page this is considered part of the largest

metric because it's not going to be ready in time so if you are using nextjs

so for the remaining of the talk we're going to talk about loading and prioritization and how we can optimize
that with HTML I'm going to give a very simple basic rundown of prioritization
just to set some background for you um it's a very complex area so when I say
basic I mean basic let's do the best that we can so with prioritization
uh in HTTP 1 browsers would typically open multiple TCP connections and it
would load one resource at a time so prioritization was based on whatever was requested
first however in http2 and HTTP 3 rather than multiple connections it was
typically changed to a single connection with multiple requests but that doesn't mean that all
the requests can be responded to at the same time
sorry but because that's not how it works right this is because a connection is
limited in how much data that it can send and that's particularly true at the start of a connection because data is
limited uh for the each network round trip as a result the server is going to
decide what to respond to First this means that the order of
prioritization can have a big impact to the performance of your website or
application because as it prioritizes one thing it's going to deprioritize
another so if you send your JavaScript first uh your images will be delayed and vice versa and this is particularly
important for render blocking resources like JavaScript and CSS because they
need to be downloaded in full before they can be applied and executed on the page and even more confusingly uh
browser prioritization actually varies between browsers it is not not the same so you might notice differences between
F Fox Chrome Safari Edge depending on how you have things
set up so one of the ways that we can sort of handle these issues is with priority
hints specifically the fetch priority attribute what fetch priority does is
allow you to specify the priority that you want for TP resource types like CSS
fonts images and Scripts and it'll allow you uh to suggest to the browser what
important level it is but also try and uh resolve some of those discrepancies
between the browsers by providing that information it has three values High
means you want to prioritize it low means you want to deprioritize it and
auto means you're happy to let the browser do its thing that is the default now often people will expect if
you set it to high it'll be the highest priority and if you set it to low it'll be the lowest
priority that is not what it does uh it actually sets a relative priority so it
will raise or lower the browser's default priority by a specified amount
so it's kind of more like a suggestion than a demand as an example um this is from
web.dev so it is Chrome based we have a critical CSS
um style sheet if we set it's sorry it's default priority is the highest priority because
it's a render blocking resource if we set the fetch priority to high it's going to retain the highest priority
which is great if we set it to low it's not going to become a low priority it's just going
to be downgraded to a high priority because it's still important as far as the browser is concerned because CSS
tends to be render blocking so in neither of these cases is are we explicitly saying it's high or
low we're just adjusting the relative priority unfortunately the browser rules
are not very well documented there is some information online uh Robin Marx
has investigated it a little bit I've linked to his resources um probably his is the best I found so you can go check

important so it's best to keep preconnect for only the critical connections for everything else you can
